page.title: 01LANDSCAPE OF SOUTH INVERKIP
page.content: The area lies on the eastern side of the Firth of Clyde between the villages of{Inverkip}and{Wemyss Bay. The altitude ranges from sea-level in the extreme northwest near Inverkip, to 276m in the southeast. The low-lying western part is used mainly for dairy farming while the upper slopes in the east are mainly heather moorland, which is used for sheep farming with some areas of forestry. The{Daff Resevoir}lies to the north east. This is part of the aqueduct, known as the{Cut,}which formerly supplied{Greenock's}water. The only settlement, apart from farms is the Southern part of Inverkip village and the Langhouse Hotel. Communications are limited to minor roads connecting the various farms in the area, except for the A78 in the northwest which joins Inverkip and Wemyss Bay.
